w:r.w:t: I have worked with Pete for 12 years and have seen him grow up over that time. Undeniably, our business would be less of a business without him. Pete sits on the full board at Evolution having joined us as a junior (the only person in group history to have made this transition).

On a professional level, Pete deals with data and is good at it. Pete also has management skills, running an IT team of 12 in disparate disciplines ranging from the database (his core skill) to our development and infrastructure teams. Pete is good humoured, fun to be around but serious when he needs to be.
In his time working at Evolution Pete has:
Scaled up the database from eight users in one office in one country to 150 users in five offices spread across the world
Overseen the introduction of our own private cloud
Built the entire support infrastructure including, but not limited to: introduction of helpdesk, decreasing the maintenance window from fourteen to two hours, enabling 24-hour uptime
Devolved our total dependence on a software house (a £100k pa expense) by bringing development in house
Introduced Lean-Agile project management and, in turn, Kanban (so successfully that we now use it in our sales teams as well as our IT team)
Pete’s even contributed to the bottom line bringing in leads worth well over £150K
What is perhaps more impressive is that Pete barely takes time out to notice any of this. Choosing instead to focus on that which is not yet done, that which could still be improved
Nick Elliott, Owner, Evolution Recruitment Solutions
It all begins with the data. Evolution had lots of it and a SQL Server. What’s more they had ambition. If that SQL Server was the

. Initially I was on a three-month contract to deduplicate the data, soon afterwards I was coding Machine Learning algorithms. By the time I left Evolution were Microsoft Gold Partners whose systems where the envy of an entire industry; the IT team was fourteen-strong but their habits (e.g. Scrum/Kanban/Scrumban) were enterprise-wide. But it all took slightly longer than three months.

It was a pleasure to work with Pete for over 12 years during which time he built and lead an outstanding IT team which helped Evolution gain huge competitive advantage from the innovative bespoke software they've developed. Pete's passion and enthusiasm are infectious and was a great ambassador for Evolution. I would have no hesitation in recommending Pete.
Gareth Morris, CEO, UK & Europe, Evolution Recruitment Solutions

I joined the board of Evolution in 2012 and the full board one year later. The first person ever to break into the inner circle having been a junior in the company. Of my twenty years in the data industry, this period was my least hands-on because the new role demanded my input at a higher level. I was a manager before this role but I learned about management during it.
Skills used: SQL Server 2012, SSAS, SSRS, SSIS, C#, ASP.Net, VB.Net, VBA, R, Power BI, VMWare, Excel

Pete built the impressive data warehouse (i.e. the model, the DB, the processes around it and its place in the business) at Evolution. This warehouse is a clear competitive advantage that has significantly contributed to Evolution's market advantage
The infrastructure Pete built to make this data accessible for Evolution's international offices was that of a much larger or more technologically centric company.
After two year at Evolution my job title changed from Data- to IT- Manager. My main passion remained data
but the still small business need a comprehensive function and I was the obvious

candidate to lead it. This period began with the great recession, moved to a period of rapid UK-based expansion and culminated in a small single-brand, single-office, single-country, single-language company, to a multi-national, multiple brand enterprise.
Pioneering of Database as a Service model (on SQL Server 2008) to allow a franchise-based business model.
Migration from SQL Server 2000 to SQL Server 2008.
Establishment of scalable helpdesk function with replicable job units.
Build and A/B testing of commercial websites.
Skills used: SQL Server 2008, SSAS, SSRS, SSIS, VB.Net, VBA, VB6, , Excel
Big learns: communication to board, educational platform for
mail server management, active directory management

My initial role at Evolution started when I was younger and more audacious. “If you can say it, I can code it” were the exact words that left my mouth. Whilst I never quite regretted them, it led to some interesting projects. Simply, no idea was too big and the projects we worked on then would one day be called “Data Science”.
Establishment of Data Team plus basic support infrastructure.
Introduction of per-consultant MI using SQL Server and ASP.
and importing in SQL Server VB.Net and VB6.
Wages automation in SQL Server and classic ASP.
Early machine learning for email analysis.
Skills used: SQL Server 2000, VB.Net, Excel, VBA, VB6,
Big learns: interaction with software house, recruitment industry

was an inspirational manager who developed a database that incorporated data quality, master data, fuzzy string matching, self-service BI and was industry certifications before any of that was mainstream
James Baldwinson, Senior Consultant at Coeo Ltd (reported to Pete)

subject matter expert. If this seems unreasonable: it was. I didn’t enjoy working at
but I did learn a lot.
Big learns: interviewing, how to manage a person, coping with hostility, communication to clien
ts, communication to management, B2B direct marketing industry.
Pete joined my data development team at Inter
Act as the company transitioned from an Excel-based analytics model to a Business Objects one
Dan Jankowski, Senior Oracle Developer, Société Générale
LAP, ROLAP, Set-based programming using Business Objects Software.
Providing, interpreting and automating reports for sales teams.
Skills used: Excel, VBA, Business Objects
iting reports for sales teams, communicating data analysis, Excel macro writing, FMCG industry
I have scaled many of Europe’s highest peaks. I hiked fifty miles in a day for charity. I have visited every US state apart from Hawaii – and wrote a (bad)

I follow football, cricket, baseball and NFL. Sometimes to a level bordering on excessive. Ditto rock music, popular science and computing. I am genuinely passionate about my muse and don’t differentiate studying about data from reading for pleasure.
In my spare time I like to perform stand-up and improv.
is also one of the most entertaining presenters I have had the pleasure to see.

This has been such a worthwhile training day. I will recommend it to all my relevant colleagues. Amazing thank you Pete. It will be a light bulb moment! put the data subject first and then it all makes sense, very clever.
Head of Student Services, Large UK University (audience member for GDPR training full day)
spends their spare time performing improve and stand-up comedy
, it stands to reason that I like public speaking
. As a data professional I am fortunate enough to get invited to speak in locations as far afield as
, Copenhagen but mostly Manchester. I have spoken in public on the
facets of data that mean most to me: how to code well, how to communicate data by visualisation, to your boss and, fundamentally, how to keep this ethical.
I have visualised my thirty most recent speaking engagements
In addition to speaking at numerous events to promote the virtues of using data correctly, I have volunteered for the following organisations:
Organise the annual SQL Saturday conference (300 attendees)
to work, and this has always been true. I include my late-nineties internships because they taught me so much. (If you want to know just how much then click the links)
A true genius in all senses, with lashing of personality that helps anyone who Pete engages with want to hear more
Education is important to me. Studying Data Science has taught me the why behind the data things I do; coalesced it into a body of knowledge as opposed to a bag of tricks.
Yep, I am still proud of my A-level results.
